dialogues.text: I'm a fifth rate clown when second rate circuses are folding all over the place. Doesn't put me on top of Ringling's list. They've got a dozen of me in the wings. I couldn't even go if I wanted to. August won't pay anyone. Says the show's debts have to come first. First time in Benzini Bros history performers haven't been paid. People are starving out there, Jacob. In the United States of America. Starving. Where am I going to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about family? Like my son. Gotta have somebody...a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a woman I have any use for. She's sold me to this outfit when I was 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sold you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly cut out for farm work. Don't worry about me..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..If you and Marlena go, if August doesn't kill you first - I'll know what to do...I'll tell August how well I got to know you and how I can help him find you. Might even get myself a better room out of the bargain... It won't be anything personal, you understand. Beat. Each wants the other to survive at any cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do whatever you have to, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Jacob. They exchange a final look, which is a goodbye. Walter tu away from Jacob, holding Queenie to his chest. Camel looks compassionately at Jacob and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya poor kid. The night this train passed ya...you shoulda kept on running, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camel and Walter are snoring, asleep with their backs to Jacob. Queenie is asleep, nestled in Walter's arms. Jacob struggles to raise himself up. His world spins. He holds tight to the bedroll, until the spinning subsides. Jacob is a man with a mission. His eyes focus on: Walter' Knife, sticking out from beneath Walter's pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is moving fast. The rain has returned. Jacob is making his way towards the back of the train, as moves forward. He holds the knife in his mouth...moving l a tightrope walker over the wet train roof, as rain pours When he reaches the car's end, he takes a deep breath. Wi all his strength, he leaps across the divide between the and lands, clinging to the top rail, panting like a dog.
He removes the knife from his mouth, having cut his lip. licks the blood back and replaces the knife, this time keeping his lips retracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob leaps to the roof of Marlena and August's car. At t moment, the train is making a curve. Jacob climbs down over the side ladder. Beyond him, we se

dialogues.speaker: BOULDERS OF A RIVERBANK ILLUMINATED BY MOONLIGHT.
dialogues.text: Jacob jumps to the platform. He can see the rocky waters below the trestle. He catches his breath and waits, as th train straightens out onto land again. Jacob turns the knob of the door to the stateroom, slowly hearing a click, pausing, then opening it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob enters the stateroom, leaving the door open. He cre towards the velvet curtain which is closed. He grips the knife. When he reaches it, he pulls the edge and peeks inside. August is asleep on his side, his arms locked around Marl who is awake facing the curtain. Jacob and Marlena's eyes meet. She sees the knife in his August suddenly moves, pulls Marlena closer to his chest, burying his face in her neck. Jacob steps forward, raising the knife. His hands tremble The moonlight glints off the blade, throwing off light. Marlena is looking up at him, tears in her eyes. She subt shakes her head "NO"...She doesn't want him to do this. Jacob's hands are shaking now. The knife gripped in his h He wants to rescue her, he's so close. We hold the moment Marlena's expression convinces Jacob not to do it...not t cross that line and kill August.

Defeated, Jacob kneels beside her and hangs his head. Mar reaches out to touch him...this time she really is saying goodbye. But Jacob can not bear it. He looks at her for t last time, then rises and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob returns to the ring stock car, hopping down from th roof. The Horses are stirring, agitated. He calms them... And then Jacob sees: the door to Walter's room is open. H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter? Camel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob enters to find the room in a shambles. A terrible realization comes over him: Walter and Camel are gone. They have been red-lighted.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He finds Queenie, shaking with fear curled in a ball. He takes her in his arms. Jacob panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No..no..no..no....!!!! With Queenie, he rushes back into the ring stock car...he checks everywhere calling out their names. He stops at th open stock car door. The rain continues to fall. Jacob collapses, holding Queenie to his chest. Tears fill his e as he tries to hold it together, looking out the moving train, his worst nightmare realized.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wanted to believe taking Walter's knife didn't make a difference. But still. I left him without a fighting chance. Maybe they survived. Maybe they were tossed over grassy land...I couldn't let myself believe what I already knew. Jacob falls apart, crying without shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny day. The circus is completely set up. Townsfolk, rubes, are already buying tickets for the matinee.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I waited almost til matinee time so I could let myself be seen by as many people from town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob opens the ring stock car and jumps out, holding Queenie. He hasn't slept all night. As he walks through the circus grounds, working men like and performers like Barbara are shocked to see him alive. With a fool's courage, he brazenly walks past Blackie and men, cutting a path through performers and working men, r up to August, who stands with Earl at his side. He is dre and ready for the matinee's performance. Jacob stops and they exchange looks. August glances at Queenie in Jacob's arms. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here to cause any trouble. I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, I thought you already left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to say goodbye. To the menagerie. Just a few minutes and then I'll go. August's eyes narrow. Earl waits for the outcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing more you can do to me. Killing me'll be more trouble than it's worth, now that the rubes have seen me. You were right about me from the start August, when you said I wouldn't last...I can't survive here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am nothing.
August feels victorious and therefore benevolent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, take him to the menagerie. Thirty seconds. Then escort him out of my circus, into Altoona. And if he comes back, you can shoot him, as that is within our lawful rights with regards to trespassers. August walks away. Earl escorts Jacob to the menagerie. O the way, they pass Barbara. Jacob pauses to hand Queenie her. She has tears in her eyes. Jacob continues with Earl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob enters alone. He takes in all the animals who look at him. He crosses to Rosie and stands before her. Her tr greets him, stroking him. He presses his head against her Rosie comforts him. It makes Jacob fall apart all the mor After a few moments, Jacob turns and walks away. He stops the center of the menagerie. He looks at each animal in t den - in the same way as when he first met them - this ti saying goodbye. Each animal is at the front of it's den or cage, looking Jacob. There is a silent exchange between them. Earl ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on kid. When Jacob starts to exit again, something happens:

dialogues.speaker: BELLOWING, AS IF IN PROTEST OF THEIR JACOB'S DEPARTURE.
dialogues.text: The lock on Rex's cage busts a little as he rams against

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Earl escorts Jacob, they walk against the tide of audi members walking to the Big Top entrance. Earl speaks low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good you're going. They must have known you got back on the train last night. He tossed more than half a dozen working men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinkers never get tossed. Never. So that was meant for you. We hear the GOUNOD WALTZ starting in the Big Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few of the guys that got tossed caught up with us again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! Is he---? Instantly, Earl's expression tells Jacob it's bad news. Jacob's breathing almost stops as he listens;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep walking...They got tossed off the trestle, if you can believe it. Camel's head hit the rocks. He died right away... Jacob is heartbroken and dreads what he's about to hear. pauses for a beat...this part is harder to tell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Walter...Walter's legs were smashed up real bad..They had to leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't reckon he lasted the night. Jacob is in shock. He can barely walk on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones that came back...Bill... Grady.. I don't know how but, one way or another they're taking down August tonight. Hearing this, Jacob stops to face Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me? Earl can not find the words: it's clear the killing of th men does not sit well with him.

dialogues.speaker: A CYMBAL'S HOLLOW CLANG.
dialogues.text: Earl shifts his focus - he's alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, what was that? All the performers and work men on the midway are on aler

dialogues.speaker: WE HEAR THE BIG TOP BAND START PLAYING AGAIN...THIS TIME
dialogues.text: "STARS AND STRIPES FOREVER".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ! Oh Shit... Earl runs back towards the Big Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Disaster March! Everyone with the show barrels towards the Big Top when G appears amongst them and calls to Jacob:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob shoots through the tent flap and is immediately flu up against the sidewall as:

dialogues.speaker: THE YAK THUNDERS PAST HIM, HIS HORN INCHES FROM JACOB, TH
dialogues.text: HYENA ON HIS BACK. Jacob looks to the menagerie and faces
Jacob is scanning the tent for Marlena when:

dialogues.speaker: WHEN BOBO SWINGS FROM A ROPE AND JUMPS ONTO JACOB'S BACK.
dialogues.text: Jacob manages to hold Bobo in one arm and the Orangutan i the other as his eyes sweep the tent, searching for Marle Then Jacob sees - THE PANTHER MAKES IT'S WAY THROUGH THE CONNECTED WALKWAY TO THE BIG TOP AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: SWEEPING HER TO THE GROUND...
dialogues.text: Searching and dodging animals, Jacob sees a flash of pink sequins. He sees August with Marlena standing beside him, front of Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENA
dialogues.text: Marlena sees Jacob and makes a run for him, but August quickly grabs her arm and flings her to the ground. She f out of view from Jacob. Jacob runs to them, dodging the fleeing animals, when suddenly: A BULL HOOK FLIES FROM OUT OF THE AIR ACROSS TH ANIMALS AND PIERCES JACOB'S SHOULDER. He cries out. Rosie cries out. She begins to stamp her feet. Marlena li with her face in the dirt, crawling beneath the ropes to under Rosie for safety.
August pulls Jacob with a new bull hook, tossing him the ground. August glares at him, his eyes full of rage;

dialogues.speaker: YOU
dialogues.text: He attacks but Jacob dodges the next blow, grabbing onto bull hook and twisting it with such strength, it topples August who refuses to let it go... JACOB AND AUGUST FIGHT SAVAGELY, AMIDST THE STAMPEDE. Lik madmen fighting with the intention to kill. Jacob unleashes a rage and a strength we have yet to see him, as he beats August without mercy... But August manages to overpower Jacob, unleashing his own maniacal fury. By taking advantage of the bull hook wound August gets Jacob into a death grip around his neck. Marlena screams out, unable to help as animals stampede around the two men locked in combat. Only Rosie, who towers above them, knows what to do. Jacob, choking under August's grip, looks up at Rosie. Sh raises her trunk to smile at him. Jacob looks down and se that ROSIE'S STAKE HAS BEEN PULLED OUT OF THE GROUND. Jacob fights August to breathe as Rosie reveals she is holding the stake loosely, resting it's end on the dirt. chain still attached to her foot. Jacob flips himself which forces August to turn his back Rosie in order to keep his grip on Jacob. Marlena covers her head in her arms, not wanting to see. Jacob can not breathe..August is squeezing the life from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie lifts the stake as if it weighs nothing and brings down onto August, splitting his head in one clean move. S continues to hold the stake until August topples forward, dead, his skull opened like a hardboiled egg.. Released of August, Jacob rolls himself under the ropes j

Rosie then slides the stake back to the ground. Marlena, hidden under her arms, sees nothing. The menagerie is cle of the stampeding animals. Marlena lifts her head up from beneath her arms, remainin under Rosie. She sees August lifeless body. She looks to Jacob. He rises, bloodied and beaten, but alive. WIDE ANGLE: The empty menagerie except for: Jacob standin Marlena under Rosie and the two monkeys inspecting August dead body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The polar bear is walking calmly down main street.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It took days to round them up. Some we never did get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Children are delighted that a GIRAFFE is eating from their second story window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera discovers a DISHWASHER and REX THE LION, both quivering, huddled opposite each under beneath a sink.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don't know who was more scared - the rubes or the animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE NESCI BROS. CIRCUS TRAIN is pulling up alongside the "ghost town" of the Benzini Bros - the ruins of the circ are highlighted by strong winds blowing up dust and dirt.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When the Nesci Bros. Circus showed, we were officially belly up. A MAN SCREAMS after unrolling a canvas and making a disco inside. A crowd forms. When Jacob reaches it, he sees: BLACKIE, DEAD, WITH A MAKESHIFT GARROTTE AROUND HIS NECK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DICK NESCI and the Sheriff fight with Jacob over Rosie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...These animals are now the property of Altoona and we're here to sell them to Mr. Nesci.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all of them! Some of these animals are mine, like this bull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any proof? Jacob is stalled. Greg appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. He's just an elephant tramp. The bull is his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want her anyway. She can't do anything. Dumb as a box of peanut shells. Skeptical, Dick Nesci steps up to Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gertrude. Jacob and Rosie exchange eye contact. Nesci is skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gertrude! Gertrude, step up! UP! Rosie blows and swings her trunk, throwing dirt across th people around her. Dick Nesci takes the bull hook and prods under her leg, ordering her UP! Rosie just swings her ears and sniffs Di Nesci with her trunk. Then checks his pockets for treats. Jacob exchanges a look with Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob is walking Rosie, holding the Orangutan, with Bobo atop Rosie. Through the wind and dust, they look for Marl

dialogues.speaker: FROM OUT OF A WALL OF WIND BLOWN DUST APPEARS MARLENA AND
dialogues.text: OF HER BLACK AND WHITE HORSES. Marlena looks spent - shoc relieved, tearful, hopeful. She reaches Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew. Marlena exhausted, eases into Jacob's arms. It's over. WIDE ANGLE: Jacob and Marlena and their animals, as the g tent of the Benzini Bros. Big Top falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob is finishing his story. Charlie is enthralled. The first bottle of scotch is gone. The second half full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I convinced my dean to let me take my finals. Marlena was right. With my degree, our animals and Marlena's acts, Ringling got a sweet deal. Our son was born our first season. We named him Walter. He spent the first seven years of his life with Ringling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I...I just can't understand how he forgot to show up today. (His eyes glitter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a circus in town. Charlie understands. He looks affectionately at Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time our third son came, we'd had enough. Rosie was tired. (Charlie smiles. ) Luckily, the vet at the Albany Zoo dropped dead, so I got the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We bought some property so we could keep the horses...Rosie...then five kids...Bobo and that Orangutan...Never named that Orangutan. Nothing ever sounded.. elegant enough for her. Just called her Ma'am. (Smiles with great joy) Man oh man that was...that was a life, boy, I'll tell ya... Charlie smiles, appreciating this old man's big life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then before you know it, the kids are borrowing the car and moving out. Marlena and I on our own again...until she passed. This moment causes Jacob to pause. He still loves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never told Marlena it was Rosie who got August. I didn't want her to know. When Rosie passed on, she cried for days. I owe that bull my whole life...my kids, everything.. A KNOCK. Charlie peeks through the window and sees a COP:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here for me. Charlie and Jacob exchange a look. Charlie understands.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TRAILER DOOR
dialogues.text: Charlie opens the door to greet a LOCAL COP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Officer, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm hoping you can. An elderly gentleman went missing from the nursing home down the street. Staff seems to think he came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a lot of folks from the home today. But no, I haven't seen him. The Cop peers past Charlie and sees Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pause, then) Oh....that's my Dad. The Cop is suspicious. Charlie covers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't talk. Had a major stroke a few years back. But he's doing well. Ain't ya Pop? Understanding the ruse, Jacob starts to play the part of stroke victim: he opens his mouth, his jaw quivers. He reaches for his glass with a shaking arm. Charlie helps h Jacob holds out his tongue like a parrot's as Charlie hel him drink. The Cop watches with a blank expression. Jacob swallows and nods speechless, smiles and manages to drool Beat. The Cop wonders. Then, pulling out his card:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, well, thanks for your time. Here's my number in case you hear of anything. Sorry to bother you. The Cop exits. Charlie returns to sit opposite Jacob. The consider this unspoken proposal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about this? Beat as Charlie pours another shot. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if we can get you into the book of records. "Oldest man who ever ran away with the circus".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I'm not running away. Just coming home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Jacob uses his walker to enter the menagerie. He move each animal meeting his eyes with theirs. Each animal giv him a look of acknowledgment. He comes to an ORANGUTAN...younger than the one from his Benzini days. Jacob stops. He steadies himself. Jacob lets go of the walker and reaches his arm out to th Orangutan's cage. The Orangutan studies him for a moment. Judging. Jacob keeps his arm extended, which isn't easy for him. The Orangutan then extends his hand through the bars to Jacob's hand. Jacob's fingers entwine around the Orangutan's hand. They hold for a moment. Jacob smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ma'am.
